data.text: @serenity22 @ClintVSmith @SpeakerTrevor Great. Thanks for letting me know.

@ClintVSmith @MariaSherwood2 @JennyWi18628806 Literally all of those have been lost to the cost of living crisis (which Ardern has denied). Labour aren't willing to implement the policies needed to help. They have left a minimum wage that  is poverty, and beneficiaries worse off than ever.

@JennyWi18628806 no. someone on the median income gets $2 a week from the Nats' plan. They have experienced $60 a week of inflation since 2017.

It's higher minimum wage, superannuation increases, benefit increases, Winter Energy Payment, Best Start, Working for Families etc that help them.
@JennyWi18628806 No. National's plan gives $2 a week to someone on $40,000 a year (roughly median income). That person has experienced about $35 a week of inflation on average in the last year
@AxelWilkeNZ @ClintVSmith @SpeakerTrevor they are already doing this as a hybrid model.
@ClintVSmith For the people who are really struggling, would a tax adjustment make much difference?

@nealejones oh true

what wonders hath God wrought
@ClintVSmith Like when your managers in that airline u used to run, had a  'I wouldn't describe it that way' routine to hide issues fm the CAA with tea & lamingtons sessions.
@ClintVSmith Shifting the tax brackets won't help those on the bottom rung. You'd have to lower the bottom tax rate to do that but we know National don't really understand how income tax works.

@ClintVSmith Making public transport free of charge would probably have a bigger impact in terms of reducing the cost of living for those at the mid to bottom end than having bracket adjustmenet resulting in a massive extra $2-$10 per week.
